tags.title: Learning Objective
value: Explain the causes of the Columbian Exchange and its effects on the Eastern and Western Hemispheres.
Explain the continuities and changes in economic systems and labor systems from 1450 to 1750.
Explain the continuities and changes in networks of exchange from 1450 to 1750.
Explain how economic developments from 1450 to 1750 affected social structures over time.

tags.title: Thematic Focus
value: As societies develop, they affect and are affected by the ways that they produce, exchange, and consume goods and services.

A variety of internal and external factors contribute to state formation, expansion, and decline. Governments maintain order through a variety of administrative institutions, policies, and procedures, and governments obtain, retain, and exercise power in

The process by which societies group their members, and the norms that govern the interactions between these groups and between individuals, influence political, economic, and cultural institutions and organization.

tags.title: Historical Development
value: The Atlantic trading system involved the movement of goods, wealth, and labor, including enslaved people.

The new global circulation of goods was facilitated by chartered European monopoly companies and the global flow of silver, especially from Spanish colonies in the Americas, which was used to purchase Asian goods for the Atlantic markets and satisfy Chine

European colonization of the Americas led to the unintentional transfer of disease vectors, including mosquitoes and rats, and the spread of diseases that were endemic in the Eastern Hemisphere - including smallpox, measles, and malaria. Some of these dis
The new connections between the Eastern and Western Hemispheres resulted in the exchange of new plants, animals, and diseases, known as the Columbian Exchange.

Newly developed colonial economies in the Americas largely depended on agriculture, utilized existing labor systems, including the Incan mit'a, and introduced new labor systems, including chattel slavery, indentured servitude, encomienda and hacienda syst

The demand for labor intensified as a result of the growing global demand for raw materials and finished products. Traditional peasant agriculture increased and changed in nature, plantations expanded, and the Atlantic slave trade developed and intensifie

Although the world's productive systems continued to be heavily centered on agriculture, major changes occurred in agricultural labor, the systems and locations of manufacturing, gender and social structures, and environmental processes.
